title: Rugby World Cup: Wales and New Zealand want drinking game over third-place play-off, says Gatland
text:
Warren Gatland’s Wales fell just short in the semi-finals against South Africa (Picture: Getty Images)

Wales coach Warren Gatland says both his team and New Zealand might have preferred a drinking game to the World Cup third-place play-off ahead of them on Friday.

Both teams go into the contest after the huge disappointment of losing World Cup semi-finals, Wales falling just short against South Africa, while the All Blacks were stunned by England.

Gatland admits that motivation has been difficult to come by for the match, but also believes that any chance to play New Zealand is a special occasion, even if a drinking contest would be more fun.

‘It’s the last game you want to be involved in, but it’s been on the calendar and everyone has known about it,’ said Gatland.

‘I think New Zealand’s CEO Steve Tew made a joke to our chief executive Martyn Phillips that both teams should have a boat race and we could settle it that way!

‘I can see the relevance in that! When you put the disappointment behind you, you think about the chance to play the All Blacks and that gets you excited. Hopefully as coaches we’ve put the disappointment of the last 48 hours behind us and can start getting excited for the next 24.

New Zealand were humbled by England in the final four (Picture: PA Wire)

‘It’s the same for the group of players. We want to go out, perform well, and be positive about the way we play. I think the All Blacks will play the same way.

‘Both teams are quite similar in terms of the synergy we are trying to achieve with the selection. Both of us will want to be positive in the way we want to play.’

Wales might not be able to lift the World Cup, but they can make some history still, by beating the All Blacks for the first time in well over half a century.

‘It has been a long time, 66 years not to beat a side,’ continued Gatland. ‘We have had success against every other nation; the All Blacks have been that elusive team we have not been able to conquer.’

New Zealand coach Steve Hansen is taking charge of his final game with the All Blacks, and insists that his side are absolutely motivated to succeed.

‘There’s been a lot of external talk around this being the game that no one wants to play,’ said the two-time World Cup winning coach. ‘However, from our point of view, we can’t wait to play it. Everyone in the squad – players and management – are motivated by the opportunity to show that our last performance wasn’t at the high standard that we know we can play at.

‘This is a Test match against an opposition that will also be keen to make a statement. Therefore, we will need to turn up with real attitude, intent and work ethic, and then execute our skillsets to the highest level possible. The game will be physical and fast as both teams will look to play to their strengths.’

The Bronze Final is played at the Tokyo Stadium at 9am UK time on Friday.
